item.title: Developing a Research Propsal
item.description:
Now that you have a few ideas in mind, we need to work on developing those ideas into something that looks more like a research project. This section of the workshop will provide some basic structure to help you with that process.

View slides in new window

item.title: Developing a Research Idea
item.description:
Congratulations on passing your core exams!! At this point, you’re probably starting to stress about how to begin the transition into research. In this section, we’ll work through some best practices for developing research ideas. We’ll also talk to some senior graduate students about their experiences in the 2nd year.

View slides in new window

item.title: Who completes the program and why?
item.description:
While there are many, many reasons that someone may not finish a PhD program, I think most of them can fit into one of three general areas:

  1. Match with “PhD life”
  2. Match with program
  3. Allocation of effort

In these slides, we’ll talk a bit more about these areas and what I think they mean.

View slides in new window

item.title: Good Examples of Bad Behaviors
item.description: Oh man, there are some strange stories out there. Let’s talk about just a few examples of things that you definitely should not do.

item.title: Early and Often
item.description:
Perhaps the key to writing is actually writing. What does that mean? It means you need to force yourself to start writing early and often. Students usually spend way too much time thinking about what they want to write and avoiding actual writing. Research is not linear…you can’t just do the work and then prepare the paper.

Here, we’ll talk about some specific strategies for incorporating writing into the research process, so that it becomes both an input and an output.

View slides in new window

item.title: Organize Your Projects
item.description:
So you have a great idea?! That’s awesome. Chances are, this great idea didn’t come to you while you were sitting comfortably in your office/research space, ready to calmly write down some ideas and carefully organize things. If you’re like me, you have an idea when you’re riding your bike, or laying down to watch TV before you go to bed, or when your kids are all having a breakdown and you decide to reorient your research toward to costs and benefits of corporal punishment.

Here, we’ll share some things that seem to work for organizing your research ideas and, eventually, your full research projects.

View slides in new window

item.title: Presenting and attending conferences
item.description:
You’ve written a complete paper - yay!! Now you need to get your results out there in front of people, and a common way to do that is to go present your work.

Here, we’ll talk about norms and expectations for conferences and go over some rules for improving your presentations.

View slides in new window

item.title: Understanding the job market
item.description:
So you’re thinking about going on the job market next year? Well, before we talk about how to do that successfully, let’s talk about what the job market is like.

View slides in new window

item.title: Collecting materials for the job market
item.description:
At this point, you should have a couple of papers under your belt, and it’s time to start thinking about other things you need to begin to enter the job market…things like a CV, a syllabus, etc. Here, we’ll work through some basic requirements and suggestions for these stand-alone documents.

View slides in new window

Be sure to check the resources page to access any Emory-specific templates.

item.title: Distributing materials for the job market
item.description:
Now that you have all of this content that highlights what a great researcher/teacher/analyst you are, how do you make it accessible to others? Here, we’ll make sure everyone has a functional website for their time on the job market.

View slides in new window

The slides are really just general overview and basic rules to consider. Details are available on the resources page.

item.title: Who completes the program and why?
item.description:
Having talked about common reasons students don’t finish the program, let’s now turn to some tips for successfully completing a PhD. But if you haven’t already, please also take a look at our Etiquette page. So much of “success” really just boils down to being a good example and helping to create a positive culture.

Or, as Helen Mirren put it:

Below are some slides that go through some specific ways to help you successfully complete the PhD program.

View slides in new window

item.title: Best Practices for Writing Academic Papers
item.description:
There’s no strict formula for writing a good academic paper, but there are certainly some guidelines to help improve the probability of writing a good paper. Here, we’ll talk about some simple rules you can try to follow to improve your writing.

View slides in new window

item.title: Version Control and File Management
item.description:
Help your future self (and others) by keeping track of your research. This is particularly critical if you’re doing any sort of empirical work. How exactly did you deal with those odd values? Which observations did you drop and why? Didn’t you already try that approach before? Where are those results?

Here, we’ll cover some best practices for keeping track of your work. This is effectively all about replicability, but it’s also about improving your research efficiency. I also have a GitHub repo and short videos on our Resources page that cover some of the specifics.

View slides in new window

item.title: How to Keep Yourself (Somewhat) Organized
item.description:
If you don’t already, you’ll eventually feel pulled in many directions between teaching, service, and research. You’ll have similar pressures outside of academia. Here, we’ll talk about different organization strategies and what might work best for you.

View slides in new window

item.title: Quickly summarizing your work for the public
item.description:
You’ve written a complete paper - yay!! Now pick someone you know outside of academia and imagine they find your paper. Would they care at all? How would you describe your work (briefly and compellingly) to them?

Here, we’ll talk about some simple strategies for quickly summarizing your work for a potentially non-academic audience (or at least an audience not specifically in your field).

View slides in new window

item.title: Professional rules to live by
item.description:
We’ll go through some specific examples of what not to do and some specific strategies that I think can help us all be better professionals. But I think a lot about “being professional” can be summarized in three simple rules:

Rules of Etiquette
1. Give others the benefit of the doubt
2. Always assume you made the mistake until proven otherwise
3. Respect others’ time

“Others” means everyone, not just “other professors”

Follow the links to the left for some extra information in specific areas.

item.title: What's the point?
item.description:
The purpose of this 3rd year workshop is to share some of best practices and general advice with you, not for you to become a research robot. Every project is different, so there really isn’t a single best way to approach every project. But with a good foundation, you should find it easier to revisit old projects (e.g., after 6+ months waiting for reviews), identify promising new research, quickly filter out bad ideas, and write more compelling papers that (some) people actually want to read.

There are two central goals to the 3rd year workshop:

1. Improve your workflow

Understand some best practices for the research workflow, including strategies for collecting and organizing your ideas, replicability and version control, and backing up your work.

This is something that can save you a ton of time. With a good workflow, you can sort through ideas quickly and efficiently, organize literature reviews quickly, and keep track of what you’ve done (and what you want to do) for lots of projects. Most academics have wasted weeks of time due to bad workflow (myself included). Hopefully we can avoid some portion of this lost time for you.

2. Become a better writer

Most of us like to think of ourselves as good writers. Unfortunately most of us are probably wrong. As part of this workshop, we’ll share some general guidance on how to write an academic paper, including some ideas for a better “writing workflow” to ensure you’re writing as efficiently as possible.

item.title: What's the point?
item.description:
The main goal of the 4th year workshop to help you sell yourself as best as possible on the job market. We’ll do this in three steps:

1. Disseminating

What are the best ways to get your work out there? How do conferences work? Should you write that op-ed that someone told you to write? Can (and how should) you use social media? We’ll offer some thoughts on all of these things. We’ll also help you get a decent (and free!) website together to make sure your work is easily accessible to anyone interested.

2. Presenting

Presenting your work in different venues can be tricky. How do you best prepare for a “long-form” presentation like an invited talk or a smaller conference? What about a larger conference with shorter presentation times? What about when you run into someone in the elevator who asks what you’re working on and you only have 30 seconds? We’ll talk about how best to prepare for all of these different situations. We’ll also talk about conference etiquette.

3. Preparing for the job market

Finally, let’s go through our checklist to ensure you have all of the required elements of a well-prepared job market candidate. Does your CV look professional? Is your website fully functional with the right types of links? Have you decided where you’d like to apply and prepared your committee accordingly? If you’re going on the academic market, have you prepared the non-research parts of your packet (a good syllabus and any other teaching material)?

item.title: Tips for Email Etiquette
item.description:
Ugh, emails. No one likes email. But it can be extremely efficient if we would all just try a little. Here, we’ll talk about some strategies for keeping it professional in your email communication and hopefully minimizing some otherwise wasted time.

View slides in new window

item.title: Understanding the publication process
item.description:
You’ve written a complete paper - yay!! You’ve presented the paper and gotten lots of great comments - well done! Now you have to prepare for the insanity that is the publication process.

Here, we’ll set expectations for when you finally try to publish that perfect paper you’ve written.

View slides in new window

item.title: Avoid Catastrophe
item.description:
For heaven’s sake, save and backup your damn work!! With all of the resources available, there’s really no excuse for losing work anymore; although I’ve heard some horror stories of several drives failing at once, the data on which was proprietary and unlikely to be re-released to the researchers. This is scary.

Here, we’ll talk about some basic tips for backing up your data and all of your work. When someone later asks you for your code or your data, you really shouldn’t be able to say that you lost it.

View slides in new window

item.title: Tips for Attending Meetings
item.description:
If email is useful, it’s as a substitute for meetings. But meetings are necessary part of any workplace. Here, we’ll talk about some basic norms of office meetings.

View slides in new window

item.title: Contribute Positively to Your Office or Department Culture
item.description:
An “office culture” is hard to define. It’s basically a system of values, shared assumptions, and group norms. I believe that strong, positive culture can help develop junior faculty, improve teaching, and even improve our research. There’s certainly plenty of evidence that a strong culture helps in a traditional office setting.

As academics, we’ve often developed some odd work habits. Here, we’ll talk about some things we should consider and try to improve upon if we want to enjoy our workplace.

View slides in new window
